intro: Viscum obscurum var. longifolium, commonly known as the long-leaved mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that grows on the branches of various host trees. It has small, oval-shaped leaves that are typically arranged in opposite pairs along its stems. The plant produces white or pale green berries that contain sticky seeds, which adhere to the bark of host trees for germination. It is native to regions of North America, particularly in the eastern United States. Its botanical features make it an important component of forest ecosystems, supporting a variety of insect and bird life.
